newsitem.title: UKRAINE: Ukraine confident on multi-billion dollar IMF deal.
newsitem.headline: Ukraine confident on multi-billion dollar IMF deal.

text.p: Ukraine's Economy Minister Yuri Yekhanurov said on Friday he was confident the International Monetary Fund would decide by the end of the month to grant Ukraine a long-term, multi-billion dollar credit.

"Yes," said Yekhanurov when asked by Reuters whether the IMF, with a mission visiting Kiev until next week, would decide to give Ukraine the three-year, $2.5-3 billion Extended Fund Facility (EFF) this month.
"The talks are going normally and openly. They are prepared for mutual work and they want to help us," said Yekhanurov, who first met mission members on Thursday.
"One of the IMF's chief requirements was that Ukraine pass a budget, which we have done. Right now they are evaluating it," he said.

IMF senior officials said last week the funding body was considering replacing the EFF, given to countries implementing deep structural reforms, with an interim stand-by credit until Ukraine met 41 mutually-agreed conditions.
"Fourteen of the points are not fulfilled," Yekhanurov said.

He said a chief area of contention was IMF demands that Ukraine lower the payroll tax to 40 percent from 48.5 percent, as a first step in legalising an economy which is estimated to be 60 percent off the books.
There were also disagreements over taxes and deregulation, he added.
"Unfortunately, since these issues are tied with the process of law-making, Ukraine has not fulfilled them," he said.
Ukraine's parliament, dominated by conservatives, passed the 1997 budget nearly six months late on June 27 -- and still must approve seven of nine tax laws to underpin the budget.
The EFF would succeed an $867 million stand-by credit which expired in February.
